The Lord is My Shepard

Psalm
A reflection in a time of despair.
Author

Colin C.

Published

June 29, 2024

It’s our 28th anniversary and this has been the hardest year of our lives. Sam is doing well but still has cancer and it remains unknown if it can be stopped.

This morning Tina asked me to meditate on Psalm 23.

My reading is dark. Today I receive little comfort from this Psalm. The only comfort is in the recognition of the pain and torment of our current situation.

Psalm23 My response

The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want.

 And yet I am left in want. Am I a sheep, trapped in the wilderness? Where is my shepherd? I cry and it seems He does not hear.

He makes me lie down in green pastures;
 he leads me beside still waters;
 he restores my soul.

 I long for green pastures.
To be there with my family. Yet there death in him. I cannot leave him.
I cannot ignore it. Fear of death rots at my soul.

He leads me in right paths
 for his name’s sake.

I try to follow the right path,
remembering what the shepherd has taught me.

Is all of this for his name’s sake?

Even though I walk through the darkest valley,
 I fear no evil;
 for you are with me;
your rod and your staff—
 they comfort me.

Yes, this is a dark, dark valley. A valley of death. Though I fear no eternal evil, I fear. Are my fears not justified? The disease in real and the Lord remains silent.

Tough Your ways guide me, I question if they are any comfort.

You prepare a table before me
 in the presence of my enemies; you anoint my head with oil;
 my cup overflows.

My enemies are Death and Despair. They sit here at the table with us. Yet it seems we are the meals set before them – my son for Death and us for Despair.

There is no cup, no meal for me – rather You are serving us up.

When will you rescue us?

Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me
 all the days of my life,
and I shall dwell in the house of the Lord
my whole life long.

These seems like false hope; a lie to sooth mental anguish.

I cry as did Christ:
“My God, My God, Why have you forsaken me?”, and
”yet not what I want, but what you want.”
